[SEP] With piracy at an end, a number of towns and villages grew up along the shoreline, and the extension of the railway line to Almería in 1899 promoted the early development of the eastern region. [SEP] Alfonso XIII, just 16 years old, assumed the crown in 1902. [SEP] Prosperity and stability continued to elude the country, which remained neutral during World War I. Against a murky background of violence, strikes, and regional strife, the king accepted the dictatorship of General Miguel Primo de Rivera in 1923. [SEP] Seven years later, the opposition of radical forces toppled Primo de Rivera from power. [SEP] Alfonso XIII

[SEP] Parliamentary elections in 1933 resulted in a swing to the right, and public opinion became polarized. [SEP] When the left came out on top in the elections of 1936, the situation deteriorated at an alarming rate. [SEP] It came as no surprise when, six months later, General Francisco Franco led a large section of the army against the socialist government. column1: Founded by Phoenician traders more than 3,000 years ago, it came under Carthaginian and Roman rule before falling to the Moorish invasion force in 711. [SEP] The Moors fortified the city, developing the settlement into a major trading port serving Granada, and it was one of the last cities in Spain to be re-conquered by Christian forces in 1487. [SEP] A good place to begin a tour is at Málaga’s principle landmark, Gibralfaro (from the Arabic Jebel al Faro — Lighthouse Hill). [SEP] Located some 130 m (425 ft) above the city, this hilltop is capped by the ramparts of a Phoenician castle reconstructed in the 14th century by the Moors (who
column3: on to build the lighthouse that gave Gibralfaro its name). [SEP] The restored walls and parapets offer a superb panoramic view of both the city below and the coastline disappearing into the horizon. [SEP] Because it looks down on the Plaza de Toros, the hill also acts as free seating for bullfights taking place below. [SEP] Although it is possible to walk here, it is not recommended. [SEP] Not only is the pathway somewhat difficult in places, it is also a well-known hangout for muggers. [SEP] Best, then, to take a taxi. [SEP] Back at sea level is the delightful Paseo del Parque, with contrasting fountains at either end, which connects the old town with the Plaza de Toros. column1: Outskirts of Alicante Outside town, on the main Valencia highway, the Monasterio de Santa Verónica (Saint Veronica’s Monastery) attracts about 15,000 pilgrims and a good many hawkers during the annual May celebration of the Santa Faz (Holy Face). [SEP] Armed with canes decorated with bunches of rosemary, the participants proceed on foot to the monastery, where they venerate the Holy Face cloth that, according to tradition, retained the bloodstained image of Jesus’ face after Saint Veronica used it to wipe his brow as he
column3: to Calvary. [SEP] The sacred relic was first worshipped in the Alicante region during a drought in 1489. [SEP] As it was being carried across the site of the present-day monastery, the Santa Faz is said to have suddenly become too heavy to hold, and believers claim that a tear fell from the right eye of the image. [SEP] This was interpreted as a sign to construct the building which has housed the cloth ever since. [SEP] It can be seen at the high altar or in a chapel off the sacristy.

[SEP] At night the deep darkness of the streets is punctuated only by the neon glow of TV sets from tiny front rooms and the occasional headlights of a small colony of gas-guzzling vintage Chevrolets and Plymouths. [SEP] Havana’s distant era lives on. [SEP] Legendary places plucked from the pages of popular novels and the lives of fiction writers need little input from visitors to evoke their storied past: Graham Greene’s Hotel Sevilla, where “Our Man in Havana”
column3: to meet his secret service contact, and Hemingway’s favorite watering holes (El Floridita and La Bodeguita del Medio) and the Hotel Ambos Mundos, where he penned much of For Whom the Bell Tolls. [SEP] Old Havana is best experienced on foot, although you can also pick up a bicitaxi (pedicab) to get to the Malecón or the museums at the district’s edge.

[SEP] The War of 1812 was fostered by accumulated American grievances. [SEP] There were dramatic naval battles and a final ghastly defeat for the United States when the British burned down the city of Washington. [SEP] The Americans rushed Major General Andrew Jackson to New Orleans to command the city’s defense. [SEP] Napoleon defeated the Prussian army in several key battles and established a semi-independent Duchy of Warsaw from 1807 to 1815. [SEP] Napoleon gained an ally in Józef Poniatowski, a heralded military leader and the nephew of the last king. [SEP] The 1812 Polish War re-established the Poland-Lithuania border, but Napoleon’s troops were crushed as they advanced on Moscow. [SEP] The suicidal mission became an important rallying cry for Poles during the remainder of the 19th century.

column1: asco da Gama’s legendary sea voyage from Lisbon in the summer of 1497 — immortalized in The Lusiads (1572), the epic poem by Portugal’s national poet, Luís de Camões (1524–1580). [SEP] Rounding what is now known as the Cape of Good Hope, da Gama found what Columbus had been searching for in 1492 (although in the wrong direction): the sea-route to the lucrative spices of the East. [SEP] The Portuguese thus ended the Venetian monopoly on Eastern trade and began attracting merchants from all over Europe to Lisbon. [SEP] Portugal and Spain, the planet’s foremost maritime powers, agreed to divide the world between them by means of the 1494 Treaty of Tordesillas. [SEP] This accorded everything lying more than 370 leagues west of the Cape Verde Islands to Spain, while everything lying to the east
column3: to Portugal, thus giving Portugal a free hand in exploiting the Orient. [SEP] In 1500, Portuguese explorer Pedro Álvares Cabral accidentally reached Brazil. [SEP] Trading posts were set up all along the west and east coasts of Africa, in the Middle East (Hormuz), southern India (Goa), Malaysia (Malacca), and even in China (Macau). [SEP] Profits came primarily from trading in eastern spices, silk and porcelain, African gold, and slaves, as well as through importing copious sugar from Brazil and São Tomé.

column1: Washington gradually began to grant Puerto Ricans a greater degree of self-government and representation. [SEP] In 1900 the first civil governor was appointed (all the appointed governors were Americans until 1946). [SEP] In 1917 Puerto Ricans won a mixed bag of benefits: they were given more say in their internal affairs, made citizens of the United States — and declared eligible for conscription in World War I. [SEP] In the years between the World Wars there were continued efforts to change the island’s status and improve its quality of life. [SEP] Some, such as those who followed radical Pedro Albizu Campos, took to violence, which resulted in several assassinations, though many more insurgents worked within the system. [SEP] More Puerto Rican draftees
column3: to war in 1941. [SEP] Even while poverty lingered from the Great Depression, World War II caused continued hardship on the island because of its isolation in a dangerous sea. [SEP] But the 1940s saw the emergence of two great political figures: Luis Muñoz Marín, son of Muñoz Marín Rivera and founder of the new Popular Democratic Party, and Rexford Guy Tugwell, Governor of Puerto Rico from 1941 to 1946. [SEP] These two men were instrumental in orchestrating an amazing economic expansion that almost single-handedly converted the island from an underdeveloped backwater into a pace-setting industrial society. [SEP] Under “Operation Bootstrap,” which attracted hundreds of new factories to Puerto Rico through tax and other incentives, the per-capita income soared to the highest in Latin America.

column1: Old San Juan Old San Juan is without doubt one of the most spectacular sights of the Caribbean. [SEP] Founded in 1521, it is partially surrounded by walls and fortifications that have protected it from modernization and indiscriminate development. [SEP] The carefully preserved historic houses and public buildings retain many of the most charming features of the original Spanish colonial architecture. [SEP] Cobblestone streets (the stones were brought as ballast on the Spanish ships, which
column3: home filled with treasure and gold), tiny squares, and grand plazas surprise visitors at every turn as they wander the neat grid of streets planned four centuries ago. [SEP] Only eight blocks wide, San Juan can easily be covered on foot, though there are some steep ascents that may be challenging in the Caribbean heat. [SEP] Even if you only have one day, you’ll be able to enjoy its delights. [SEP] If possible, however, take at least a couple of days. [SEP] Enjoying a rest in a shady plaza or taking a long lunch at an outdoor café are just as much a part of your trip as a tour around the museums. [SEP] San Juan is a living city, and it’s especially bustling after dark, when crowds throng to the bars and restaurants or simply stroll the narrow streets and airy plazas.

column1: The Nao trade route continued until the early 1800s, when José María Morelos y Pavón, a hero of Mexico’s War of Independence, took over Acapulco and stopped the trade, sending the town into a century-long respite, a hiatus that ended only when the Mexican government paved the highway between Mexico City and Acapulco. [SEP] The beautiful beaches of Acapulco Bay immediately lured Mexico City’s elite, and the metamorphosis began, from slumbering trading port into the “Pearl of the Pacific,” as the media came to know it in the 1930s. [SEP] The first airplanes from the US began to arrive in the mid-1930s, and with them came a bevy of notorious visitors, from movie stars to presidents, writers to millionaires. [SEP] Acapulco became the playground for the rich and famous. [SEP] Glitzy hotels
column3: up in a hurry, supported by new boulevards, power plants, and a superhighway. [SEP] Acapulco’s peak was the 1940s to 1960s. [SEP] Celebrated images included Frank Sinatra and Ava Gardner sipping margaritas while watching cliff divers at La Quebrada, President Eisenhower meeting Mexico’s President López Mateos for a summit conference in a new high rise hotel, and Johnny Weissmuller swimming laps in the Flamingos Hotel pool overlooking Acapulco Bay. [SEP] Since those glory days Acapulco has aged — maybe not quite as gracefully as its fans would have hoped. [SEP] However, the “Perla del Pacífico” still attracts scores of vacationers, who are still regaled by old stories about the rich and famous, told by seasoned waiters as they serve pool-side drinks with a weathered but unwavering smile.
